title: Famous Doctors & Physicians
description: How well do you know the doctors who changed the world?

questions.question: Which physician is known for his pioneering work in psychoanalysis?
questions.explanation: Sigmund Freud (1856-1939) founded psychoanalysis, developing theories about the unconscious mind, dream interpretation, and the structure of personality.

questions.question: Who was the first woman to receive a medical degree in the United States?
questions.explanation: Elizabeth Blackwell received her MD from Geneva Medical College in 1849, becoming the first woman to earn a medical degree in the United States.

questions.question: Dr. Albert Schweitzer, who won the Nobel Peace Prize, set up a hospital in which continent?
questions.explanation: Albert Schweitzer established a hospital in Lambarene, Gabon (Africa) in 1913, where he treated patients for decades. He won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1952.

questions.question: Which doctor developed the Apgar score used to assess newborn health?
questions.explanation: Dr. Virginia Apgar developed the Apgar score in 1952, a quick assessment performed at 1 and 5 minutes after birth to evaluate a newborn's health.

questions.question: Dr. Benjamin Spock became famous for writing a groundbreaking book about what?
questions.explanation: Dr. Benjamin Spock wrote 'The Common Sense Book of Baby and Child Care' in 1946, which became one of the best-selling books of the 20th century.

questions.question: Which surgeon is called the 'Father of Modern Surgery' for his work in the 16th century?
questions.explanation: Ambroise Pare (1510-1590) revolutionized surgical techniques, including the treatment of wounds and the use of ligatures instead of cauterization during amputations.

questions.question: Which doctor discovered the circulation of blood through the body?
questions.explanation: William Harvey (1578-1657) published 'De Motu Cordis' in 1628, accurately describing for the first time the systemic circulation of blood pumped by the heart.

questions.question: Dr. Charles Drew made pioneering contributions in which field?
questions.explanation: Dr. Charles Drew (1904-1950) developed improved techniques for blood storage and established large-scale blood banks during World War II.

questions.question: Which ancient Greek physician's writings dominated Western medicine for over 1,300 years?
questions.explanation: Galen of Pergamon (129-216 AD) was a prolific writer whose medical theories dominated European medicine from antiquity through the Middle Ages.

questions.question: Which physician wrote 'The Canon of Medicine,' a medical encyclopedia used in Europe for centuries?
questions.explanation: Ibn Sina, known in the West as Avicenna (980-1037), wrote 'The Canon of Medicine,' which was used as a standard medical text in European universities until the 17th century.

questions.question: Dr. Michael DeBakey was a pioneer in which type of surgery?
questions.explanation: Dr. Michael DeBakey (1908-2008) was a legendary cardiovascular surgeon who developed artificial hearts, performed some of the first coronary bypass surgeries, and trained thousands of surgeons.

questions.question: Which doctor and humanitarian founded the organization Doctors Without Borders?
questions.explanation: Bernard Kouchner co-founded Medecins Sans Frontieres (Doctors Without Borders) in 1971 to provide medical aid to people affected by conflict and disasters worldwide.

questions.question: Which British doctor proved that cholera was spread through contaminated water?
questions.explanation: Dr. John Snow traced an 1854 cholera outbreak in London to a contaminated water pump on Broad Street, founding the field of epidemiology.

questions.question: Dr. James Barry, a British military surgeon, was discovered after death to have been what?
questions.explanation: Dr. James Barry (c. 1789-1865) served as a military surgeon for decades and performed one of the first successful cesarean sections. After death, it was discovered Barry was assigned female at birth.

questions.question: Which doctor developed the first effective treatment for tuberculosis?
questions.explanation: Selman Waksman discovered streptomycin in 1943, the first antibiotic effective against tuberculosis. He won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1952.
